name: Bitcrusher

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: sample_rate
options.detail: The sample rate the audio will be resampled at. This represents the number of times per second the audio is sampled. The higher the sample rate, the closer to the original the sound will be, the lower the more low-fi it will sound. The highest sample rate is 44100 (full quality) and the lowest is ~100 (extremely low quality). Try values in between such as 1000, 3000, 8000...

options.name: bits
options.detail: The bit depth of the resampled audio. Lower bit depths make the audio sound grainy and less defined. The highest bit depth is 16 (full quality) and the lowest is 1 (lowest quality).

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

detail: Creates lo-fi output by decimating and deconstructing the incoming audio by lowering both the sample rate and bit depth. The default sample rate for CD audio is 44100, so use values less than that for that crunchy chip-tune sound full of artefacts and bitty distortion. Similarly, the default bit depth for CD audio is 16, so use values less than that for lo-fi sound.

name: krush

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: gain
options.detail: Amount of crushing to serve

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Krush that sound!

name: Reverb

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: room
options.detail: The room size - a value between 0 (no reverb) and 1 (maximum reverb).

options.name: damp
options.detail: High frequency dampening - a value between 0 (no dampening) and 1 (maximum dampening)

detail: Make the incoming signal sound more spacious or distant as if it were played in a large room or cave. Signal may also be dampened by reducing the amplitude of the higher frequencies.

name: GVerb

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: spread
options.detail: Stereo spread. Amount of stereo spread the reverb has over the left and right channels. A value of 0 means no spread at all - left and right stereo values of the incoming signal are preserved. A value of 1 means full spread - the left and right channels are fully mixed within the reverb - bleeding into each other.

options.name: damp
options.detail: High frequency rolloff. 0 is no damping (the reverb will ring out more) and 1 dampens the reverb signal completely

options.name: pre_damp
options.detail: High frequency rolloff of input signal. 0 is no damping (the reverb will ring out more) and 1 dampens the reverb signal completely

options.name: dry
options.detail: Amount of original dry signal present in the effect. This is distinct from mix.

options.name: room
options.detail: The room size in squared metres

options.name: release
options.detail: Time for reverberation to complete in seconds

options.name: ref_level
options.detail: Reflection level

options.name: tail_level
options.detail: Tail level amount

detail: Make the incoming signal sound more spacious or distant as if it were played in a large room or cave. Similar to reverb but with a more spacious feel.

name: Level Amplifier

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

detail: Amplitude modifier. All FX have their own amp built in, so it may be the case that you don't specifically need an isolated amp FX. However, it is useful to be able to control the overall amplitude of a number of running synths. All sounds created in the FX block will have their amplitudes multipled by the amp level of this FX. For example, use an amp of 0 to silence all internal synths.

name: Echo

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: The time between echoes in beats.

options.name: decay
options.detail: The time it takes for the echoes to fade away in beats.

options.name: max_phase
options.detail: The maximum phase duration in beats.

detail: Standard echo with variable phase duration (time between echoes) and decay (length of echo fade out). If you wish to have a phase duration longer than 2s, you need to specify the longest phase duration you'd like with the arg max_phase. Be warned, echo FX with very long phases can consume a lot of memory and take longer to initialise.

name: Slicer

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the resulting effect.

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: The phase duration (in beats) of the slices

options.name: amp_min
options.detail: Minimum amplitude of the slicer

options.name: amp_max
options.detail: Maximum amplitude of the slicer

options.name: pulse_width
options.detail: The width of the pulse wave as a value between 0 and 1. A width of 0.5 will produce a square wave. Different values will change the timbre of the sound. Only valid if wave is type pulse.

options.name: phase_offset
options.detail: Initial phase offset.

options.name: wave
options.detail: Control waveform used to modulate the amplitude. 0=saw, 1=pulse, 2=tri, 3=sine

options.name: invert_wave
options.detail: Invert control waveform (i.e. flip it on the y axis). 0=uninverted wave, 1=inverted wave.

options.name: probability
options.detail: Probability (as a value between 0 and 1) that a given slice will be replaced by the value of the  prob_pos opt (which defaults to 0, i.e. silence)

options.name: prob_pos
options.detail: Position of the slicer that will be jumped to when the probability test passes as a value between 0 and 1

options.name: seed
options.detail: Seed value for rand num generator used for probability test

options.name: smooth
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next. Allows you to round off harsh edges in the slicer wave which may cause clicks.

options.name: smooth_up
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going up. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

options.name: smooth_down
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going down. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

detail: Modulates the amplitude of the input signal with a specific control wave and phase duration. With the default pulse wave, slices the signal in and out, with the triangle wave, fades the signal in and out and with the saw wave, phases the signal in and then dramatically out. Control wave may be inverted with the arg invert_wave for more variety.

name: Pan Slicer

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the resulting effect.

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: The phase duration (in beats) of the slices

options.name: pan_min
options.detail: Minimum pan value (-1 is the left speaker only)

options.name: pan_max
options.detail: Maximum pan value (+1 is the right speaker only)

options.name: pulse_width
options.detail: The width of the pulse wave as a value between 0 and 1. A width of 0.5 will produce a square wave. Different values will change the timbre of the sound. Only valid if wave is type pulse.

options.name: phase_offset
options.detail: Initial phase offset.

options.name: wave
options.detail: Control waveform used to modulate the amplitude. 0=saw, 1=pulse, 2=tri, 3=sine

options.name: invert_wave
options.detail: Invert control waveform (i.e. flip it on the y axis). 0=uninverted wave, 1=inverted wave.

options.name: probability
options.detail: Probability (as a value between 0 and 1) that a given slice will be replaced by the value of the  prob_pos opt (which defaults to 0, i.e. silence)

options.name: prob_pos
options.detail: Position of the slicer that will be jumped to when the probability test passes as a value between 0 and 1

options.name: seed
options.detail: Seed value for rand num generator used for probability test

options.name: smooth
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next. Allows you to round off harsh edges in the slicer wave which may cause clicks.

options.name: smooth_up
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going up. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

options.name: smooth_down
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going down. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

detail: Slice the pan automatically from left to right. Behaves similarly to slicer and wobble FX but modifies stereo panning of sound in left and right speakers. Default slice wave form is square (hard slicing between left and right) however other wave forms can be set with the `wave:` opt.

name: Wobble

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: The phase duration (in beats) for filter modulation cycles

options.name: cutoff_min
options.detail: Minimum (MIDI) note that filter will move to whilst wobbling. Choose a lower note for a higher range of movement. Full range of movement is the distance between cutoff_max and cutoff_min

options.name: cutoff_max
options.detail: Maximum (MIDI) note that filter will move to whilst wobbling. Choose a higher note for a higher range of movement. Full range of movement is the distance between cutoff_max and cutoff_min

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

options.name: phase_offset
options.detail: Initial modulation phase offset (a value between 0 and 1).

options.name: wave
options.detail: Wave shape of wobble. Use 0 for saw wave, 1 for pulse, 2 for triangle wave and 3 for a sine wave.

options.name: invert_wave
options.detail: Invert control waveform (i.e. flip it on the y axis). 0=uninverted wave, 1=inverted wave.

options.name: pulse_width
options.detail: Only valid if wave is type pulse.

options.name: filter
options.detail: Filter used for wobble effect. Use 0 for a resonant low pass filter or 1 for a resonant high pass filter

options.name: probability
options.detail: Probability (as a value between 0 and 1) that a given wobble will be replaced by the value of the  prob_pos opt (which defaults to 0, i.e. min_cutoff)

options.name: prob_pos
options.detail: Position of the wobble that will be jumped to when the probability test passes as a value between 0 and 1

options.name: seed
options.detail: Seed value for rand num generator used for probability test

options.name: smooth
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next. Allows you to round off harsh edges in the slicer wave which may cause clicks.

options.name: smooth_up
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going up. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

options.name: smooth_down
options.detail: Amount of time in seconds to transition from the current value to the next only when the value is going down. This smoothing happens before the main smooth mechanism.

detail: Versatile wobble FX. Will repeatedly modulate a range of filters (rlpf, rhpf) between two cutoff values using a range of control wave forms (saw, pulse, tri, sine). You may alter the phase duration of the wobble, and the resonance of the filter. Combines well with the dsaw synth for crazy dub wobbles. Cutoff value is at cutoff_min at the start of phase

name: Techno from IXI Lang

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: The phase duration (in beats) for filter modulation cycles

options.name: phase_offset
options.detail: Initial modulation phase offset (a value between 0 and 1).

options.name: cutoff_min
options.detail: Minimum (MIDI) note that filter will move to whilst wobbling. Choose a lower note for a higher range of movement. Full range of movement is the distance between cutoff_max and cutoff_min

options.name: cutoff_max
options.detail: Maximum (MIDI) note that filter will move to whilst wobbling. Choose a higher note for a higher range of movement. Full range of movement is the distance between cutoff_max and cutoff_min

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Moving resonant low pass filter between min and max cutoffs. Great for sweeping effects across long synths or samples.

name: Compressor

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: threshold
options.detail: Threshold value determining the break point between slope_below and slope_above.

options.name: clamp_time
options.detail: Time taken for the amplitude adjustments to kick in fully (in seconds). This is usually pretty small (not much more than 10 milliseconds). Also known as the time of the attack phase

options.name: slope_above
options.detail: Slope of the amplitude curve above the threshold. A value of 1 means that the output of signals with amplitude above the threshold will be unaffected. Greater values will magnify and smaller values will attenuate the signal.

options.name: slope_below
options.detail: Slope of the amplitude curve below the threshold. A value of 1 means that the output of signals with amplitude below the threshold will be unaffected. Greater values will magnify and smaller values will attenuate the signal.

options.name: relax_time
options.detail: Time taken for the amplitude adjustments to be released. Usually a little longer than clamp_time. If both times are too short, you can get some (possibly unwanted) artefacts. Also known as the time of the release phase.

detail: Compresses the dynamic range of the incoming signal. Equivalent to automatically turning the amp down when the signal gets too loud and then back up again when it's quiet. Useful for ensuring the containing signal doesn't overwhelm other aspects of the sound. Also a general purpose hard-knee dynamic range processor which can be tuned via the opts to both expand and compress the signal.

name: Whammy

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: transpose
options.detail: This is how much to transpose the input, expressed as a midi pitch.

options.name: max_delay_time
options.detail: The max delay time to be used for the effect. This shouldn't need to be adjusted.

options.name: deltime
options.detail: The delay time to be used for the effect. This shouldn't need to be adjusted.

options.name: grainsize
options.detail: The size of the initial grain used for transposition. This shouldn't need to be adjusted.

detail: A cheap sounding transposition effect, with a slightly robotic edge. Good for adding alien sounds and harmonies to everything from beeps to guitar samples. It's similar to pitch shift although not as smooth sounding.

name: Resonant Low Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Dampens the parts of the signal that are higher than the cutoff point (typically the crunchy fizzy harmonic overtones) and keeps the lower parts (typically the bass/mid of the sound). The resonant part of the resonant low pass filter emphasises/resonates the frequencies around the cutoff point. The amount of emphasis is controlled by the res opt with a higher res resulting in greater resonance. High amounts of resonance (rq ~1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency.

name: Normalised Resonant Low Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Dampens the parts of the signal that are higher than the cutoff point (typically the crunchy fizzy harmonic overtones) and keeps the lower parts (typically the bass/mid of the sound). The resonant part of the resonant low pass filter emphasises/resonates the frequencies around the cutoff point. The amount of emphasis is controlled by the res opt with a higher res resulting in greater resonance. High amounts of resonance (rq ~1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency.

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

The resonant part of the resonant high pass filter emphasises/resonates the frequencies around the cutoff point. The amount of emphasis is controlled by the res opt with a higher res resulting in greater resonance. High amounts of resonance (rq ~1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency.

name: Normalised Resonant High Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Dampens the parts of the signal that are lower than the cutoff point (typically the bass of the sound) and keeps the higher parts (typically the crunchy fizzy harmonic overtones). The resonant part of the resonant high pass filter emphasises/resonates the frequencies around the cutoff point. The amount of emphasis is controlled by the res opt with a higher res resulting in greater resonance. High amounts of resonance (rq ~1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency.

name: High Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

detail: Dampens the parts of the signal that are lower than the cutoff point (typically the bass of the sound) and keeps the higher parts (typically the crunchy fizzy harmonic overtones). Choose a lower cutoff to keep more of the bass/mid and a higher cutoff to make the sound more light and crispy.

name: Normalised High Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

detail: A high pass filter chained to a normaliser. Ensures that the signal is both filtered by a standard high pass filter and then normalised to ensure the amplitude of the final output is constant. A high pass filter will reduce the amplitude of the resulting signal (as some of the sound has been filtered out) the normaliser can compensate for this loss (although will also have the side effect of flattening all dynamics). See doc for hpf.

name: Low Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

detail: Dampens the parts of the signal that are higher than the cutoff point (typically the crunchy fizzy harmonic overtones) and keeps the lower parts (typically the bass/mid of the sound). Choose a higher cutoff to keep more of the high frequences/treble of the sound and a lower cutoff to make the sound more dull and only keep the bass.

name: Normalised Low Pass Filter.

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: cutoff
options.detail: MIDI note representing the highest frequencies allowed to be present in the sound. A low value like 30 makes the sound round and dull, a high value like 100 makes the sound buzzy and crispy.

detail: A low pass filter chained to a normaliser. Ensures that the signal is both filtered by a standard low pass filter and then normalised to ensure the amplitude of the final output is constant. A low pass filter will reduce the amplitude of the resulting signal (as some of the sound has been filtered out) the normaliser can compensate for this loss (although will also have the side effect of flattening all dynamics). See doc for lpf.

name: Normaliser

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: level
options.detail: The peak output amplitude level at which to normalise the input.

detail: Raise or lower amplitude of sound to a specified level. Evens out the amplitude of incoming sound across the frequency spectrum by flattening all dynamics.

name: Distortion

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: distort
options.detail: Amount of distortion to be applied (as a value between 0 and 1)

detail: Distorts the signal reducing clarity in favour of raw crunchy noise.

name: Pan

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: pan
options.detail: Position of sound in stereo. With headphones on, this means how much of the sound is in the left ear, and how much is in the right ear. With a value of -1, the sound is completely in the left ear, a value of 0 puts the sound equally in both ears and a value of 1 puts the sound in the right ear. Values in between -1 and 1 move the sound accordingly.

detail: Specify where in the stereo field the sound should be heard. A value of -1 for pan will put the sound in the left speaker, a value of 1 will put the sound in the right speaker and values in between will shift the sound accordingly.

name: Band Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: centre
options.detail: Centre frequency for the filter as a MIDI note.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Combines low pass and high pass filters to only allow a 'band' of frequencies through. If the band is very narrow (a low res value like 0.0001) then the BPF will reduce the original sound, almost down to a single frequency (controlled by the centre opt).

name: Normalised Band Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: centre
options.detail: Centre frequency for the filter as a MIDI note.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Like the Band Pass Filter but normalised. The normaliser is useful here as some volume is lost when filtering the original signal.

name: Resonant Band Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: centre
options.detail: Centre frequency for the filter as a MIDI note.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Like the Band Pass Filter but with a resonance (slight volume boost) around the target frequency. This can produce an interesting whistling effect, especially when used with larger values for the res opt.

name: Normalised Resonant Band Pass Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: centre
options.detail: Centre frequency for the filter as a MIDI note.

options.name: res
options.detail: Filter resonance as a value between 0 and 1. Large amounts of resonance (a res: near 1) can create a whistling sound around the cutoff frequency. Smaller values produce less resonance.

detail: Like the Band Pass Filter but normalised, with a resonance (slight volume boost) around the target frequency. This can produce an interesting whistling effect, especially when used with larger values for the res opt.

name: Band EQ Filter

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: freq
options.detail: Centre frequency of the band in MIDI.

options.name: res
options.detail: Width of the band as a value between 0 and 1

options.name: db
options.detail: Amount of boost or attenuation of the frequency band. A positive value boosts frequencies in the band, a negative value attenuates them.

detail: Attenuate or Boost a frequency band

name: Hyperbolic Tangent

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: krunch
options.detail: Higher values progressively destroy the sound. Achieved through a balanced manipulation of pre_amp and amp such that the tanh is pushed harder with higher krunch values yet the overall amplitude stays similar.

detail: Please write documentation!

name: Pitch shift

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: window_size
options.detail: Pitch shift works by chopping the input into tiny slices, then playing these slices at a higher or lower rate. If we make the slices small enough and overlap them, it sounds like the original sound with the pitch changed.

detail: Changes the pitch of a signal without affecting tempo. Does this mainly through the pitch parameter which takes a midi number to transpose by. You can also play with the other params to produce some interesting textures and sounds.

name: Ring Modulator

options.name: freq
options.detail: Frequency of the carrier signal (as a midi note).

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: mod_amp
options.detail: Amplitude of the modulation

detail: Attack of the Daleks! Ring mod is a classic effect often used on soundtracks to evoke robots or aliens as it sounds hollow or metallic. We take a 'carrier' signal (a sine wave controlled by the freq opt) and modulate its amplitude using the signal given inside the fx block. This produces a wide variety of sounds - the best way to learn is to experiment!

name: Octaver

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: super_amp
options.detail: Volume of the signal 1 octave above the input

options.name: sub_amp
options.detail: Volume of the signal 1 octave below the input

options.name: subsub_amp
options.detail: Volume of the signal 2 octaves below the input

detail: This effect adds three pitches based on the input sound. The first is the original sound transposed up an octave (super_amp), the second is the original sound transposed down an octave (sub_amp) and the third is the original sound transposed down two octaves (subsub_amp).

name: Vowel

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: voice
options.detail: 0,1,2,3,4 => Soprano,Alto,Counter Tenor, Tenor, Bass

detail: This effect filters the input to match a human voice singing a certain vowel sound. Human singing voice sounds are easily achieved with a source of a saw wave with a little vibrato.

name: Flanger

options.name: amp
options.detail: The amplitude of the sound. Typically a value between 0 and 1. Higher amplitudes may be used, but won't make the sound louder, they will just reduce the quality of all the sounds currently being played (due to compression.)

options.name: mix
options.detail: The amount (percentage) of FX present in the resulting sound represented as a value between 0 and 1. For example, a mix of 0 means that only the original sound is heard, a mix of 1 means that only the FX is heard (typically the default) and a mix of 0.5 means that half the original and half of the FX is heard.

options.name: pre_amp
options.detail: Amplification applied to the input signal immediately before it is passed to the FX.

options.name: phase
options.detail: Phase duration in beats of flanger modulation.

options.name: pulse_width
options.detail: The width of the pulse wave as a value between 0 and 1. A width of 0.5 will produce a square wave. Different values will change the timbre of the sound. Only valid if wave is type pulse.

options.name: phase_offset
options.detail: Initial modulation phase offset (a value between 0 and 1).

options.name: wave
options.detail: Wave type - 0 saw, 1 pulse, 2 triangle, 3 sine, 4 cubic. Different waves will produce different flanging modulation effects.

options.name: invert_wave
options.detail: Invert flanger control waveform (i.e. flip it on the y axis). 0=uninverted wave, 1=inverted wave.

options.name: stereo_invert_wave
options.detail: Make the flanger control waveform in the left ear an inversion of the control waveform in the right ear. 0=uninverted wave, 1=inverted wave. This happens after the standard wave inversion with param :invert_wave.

options.name: delay
options.detail: Amount of delay time between original and flanged version of audio.

options.name: max_delay
options.detail: Max delay time. Used to set internal buffer size.

options.name: depth
options.detail: Flange depth - greater depths produce a more prominent effect.

options.name: decay
options.detail: Flange decay time in ms

options.name: feedback
options.detail: Amount of feedback.

options.name: invert_flange
options.detail: Invert flanger signal. 0=no inversion, 1=inverted signal.

detail: Mix the incoming signal with a copy of itself which has a rate modulating faster and slower than the original. Creates a swirling/whooshing effect.
